abstracts.cdata!:
The overall achievement of the project
            objectives are judged to be highly satisfactory, with
            project sustainability highly likely. World Bank and
            Borrower performances were highly satisfactory overall.
            Theses were the lessons learned: to promote environmental
            investments which otherwise may not at all, or only very
            slowly, come about, the low cost-directed credit of the
            Ekofund for the funding of air pollution abatement projects
            was welcome, timely, and successful. And the successful
            implementation of the air pollution abatement program (APAP)
            component helped alert commercial banks to compete for this
            market so that in the near future the program would no
            longer be needed. It is important to carefully design such a
            program, to keep procedures simple, to conduct regular
            public relations campaigns, and to address potential
            customers even directly. Also, the administration of the
            program has to be carefully planned and implemented. This
            could be achieved by launching a pilot phase on a limited
            scope and choosing professional implementers. A lot of early
            campaigning had to be done to provide knowledge about the
            Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and to report the
            multifold benefits which could be derived from relatively
            small investments. This understanding is important since
            constant and sustained cooperation with potential clients
            and users for new systems, as well as sustained training of
            future users, are essential ingredients for a successful project.

5082792.trustfund: TF033171-SLOVENIA - ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT,TF033198-SLOVENIA - ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT,TF033174-SLOVENIA - ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT
5082792.majtheme: Rule of law,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Environment
            Project are to: 1) reduce ambient concentrations of
            particulate matter (for particles of less than 10 microns in
            diameter) and sulfur dioxide along with the health damage
            associated with exposure to air pollution; and 2) collect,
            organize and manage information for development and land-use
            planning, particularly in areas of Slovenia that are
            experiencing rapid development. The project consists of two
            major components: 1) an air pollution abatement component
            which will provide fuel conversion loans to about 6,500
            households and about 65 boilerhouse operators during the
            three years over which the Bank loan will be disbursed.
            These loans will be used to finance the conversion of
            heating and hot water systems currently using polluting
            fuels to the use of cleaner fuels; and 2) a geographical
            information system (GIS) component which will include the
            following: (a) the establishment of a central Geographical
            Information Center; (b) the establishment of a market
            development group to promote the use of GIS, to provide
            training (in the use of GIS), to raise market awareness on
            exchange of data and to provide assistance to regional
            administrations, government agencies and departments, and
            domestic and foreign industrial, commercial and service
            users; (c) the establishment of formal standards (in line
            with international standards) on data collection, use and
            maintenance of data and quality assurance compliance group
            to ensure that the information system operates in accordance
            with international standards; and (d) the establishment of a
            local training center in order to develop local expertise in
            the operation of GIS.
